pros:
Wonderful cause - please keep on donating!!

I have loved Oxfam for many years, the former management leadership have given me fabulous career opportunities and I would not be where I am today without them.
cons:
The new senior leadership team is TOXIC.

 I have been working for Oxfam for about 6 years, and anyone who knows and have worked with me would agree that I am such a big fan of Oxfam, of the wonderful cause we serve everyday and I have been told several times that I am probably one of the most engaged members of staff, always motivating everyone to love Oxfam. 

However, I am now leaving the company. The new senior leadership team is destroying the retail part of Oxfam. Our beautiful values of empowerment, accountability and inclusiveness are long gone and the way some of the longest serving members of staff have been treated is absolutely horrendous . 

We now operate with fake recognition - we share workplace posts and thank you cards but some our shop managers are leaving because they can't afford staying on such a low salary and we are losing our best members of staff (shout out to the volunteer engagement team who have been lifesaving over the years!) out of pure disrespect. 

Their new retail transformation team is an absolute joke - people that have proved to mess up several important transitions are now promoted project leads on vital projects for the shops.

review_title: Oxfam is lost to the cult of social justice
job_title: Supporter Relations Executive in Oxford, England
pros: Well there's a nice cafe!
cons:
Oxfam is dominated by a cabal of radical feminists and social justice warriors. Their outlook is so retrograde that they have even begun to see their own charitable work as a form of 'colonisation'. As a result, Oxfam International was moved to Kenya, for no other reason than to be 'closer' to the people the organisation works with (though further away from the people who fund the work - this wasn't mentioned), resulting in no tangible benefit for anyone at Oxfam except possibly the Chair of Trustees who invented the vanity project to boost her profile.
Are you white or male? Want to be manipulated into hating your own arbitrary characteristics? Maybe you've already been indoctrinated and are looking for somewhere which will nurture your self-loathing? Then you will fit right in at Oxfam!
Although most people believe in equality of the sexes, most - understandably - don't want to call themselves feminists and associate with the radical anti-male extremists in the movement, but at Oxfam - where these people have risen to the top through the terrified deference of their intimidated colleagues who don't wish to be 'cancelled' - you are required to call yourself a feminist, and to support feminist organisations, these are literally written into their 'core values'.
Oxfam is the sort of Orwellian place where you will be instructed what to think, and if you're even suspected of wrong-think, the authorities and their pole-climbing snitches will be all over you.
The tragedy is that Oxfam used to be a world-famous humanitarian charity, but they're quickly losing that status, and with it their support - getting woke will see Oxfam go broke, and eventually die a sad insignificant death, but the world will be better for it, real charities will rise again to take its place.

review_title: Great organisation doing great work, despite being undermined by bureaucracy and high staff turnover.
pros:
Inspiring place to work; your effort matters and will directly benefit others.
Colleagues are motivated, hard working, knowledgeable and mostly friendly.
The mix of age groups, nationalities and cultures is very interesting to be part of.
Work content is varied and stimulating, you get to see the big picture and the details.
Scope to travel to and/or learn about issues and places you'd never know about otherwise.
Oxford offers a good - but not cheap - quality of life.
cons:
Induction is prefunctory given there is a massive amount to learn in this complex organisation.  Huge bureaucracy, loads of administrative flim-flam, hard to feel effective in your role.
Inefficiency, training / intro to Oxfam courses not happening until long after they'd be useful.
Continual interruptions to attend briefings and meetings of little tangible benefit, though they did have the upside of not spending the entire day  glued to a computer screen.
Lot of silos, surprisingly little interaction between different teams/depts/confederation members.
Surprisingly high staff turnover, particularly at senior management level.
Horrible location on the ring road, no where to go at lunch except staff canteen. 
Poor payers compared to their peers.

pros: Ethics embeded in all operations

pros: I met lots of amazing people while managing the shop. Great to think you are helping people. Area Manager very nice but really had no power to help.
cons: Paid 24 hours per week but responsible for everything including targets - staffing - stock - opening hours - seven days per week. Was given a deputy manager to ‘help’ but had to ensure he didn’t exceed his twelve hours!! If volunteers or deputies don’t turn up or are unable to attend, the manager has to attend - it’s nothing for Oxfam managers to work 40 hours per week but never get paid for any of those hours. If the shop is unable to open through lack of volunteers who are prepared to take on responsibility for closing/opening safeguarding / cashing up, you are accused of not doing your job, delegation and taking on a full team of volunteers is your ‘job’ and if you’re not able to keep the shop open 6 or 7 days per week then you are constantly underperforming. Performance reviews a joke - if you struggle to open instead of helping they rate you non proficient and cut your wages - if you’re proficient- or outstanding ( exceeds expectations) you get your normal salary.  They generally only keep shop managers a couple of years / it’s an impossible job, very stressful and although HR team are supportive, they are controlled by operation directors, so they are good at seeming to say the right things! Work life balance, forget it, Oxfam have!

pros: With a few employers to compare against Oxfam is truly a great place to work. With such a huge range of business and programme activties I'm amazed at how it operated together, and how everybody felt they had a stake in the success of the organisation. From top to bottom people were really committed to doing their best for the organisation. That really permeated to the individual. It was an encouraging and inspiring environment to be in, and everybody had the chance to contribute their thoughts. Employee engagement felt high and communication was really string between the departments.
cons: Pay and reward, as expected, was a bit low and could sometimes be a bit off putting after hard work. As a graduate and in Oxfordshire at their HQ, it was hard to reconcile at the lower end of the pay scale.

pros:
- As long as you don't take the rejection personally then honestly not a bad work environment, everyone I worked with was very friendly, laid back etc.
- Good Pay 
- If you like talking and are looking for sales experience then this could be perfect.
cons:
- The reason I quit during the trail period was that the complete lack of any security was just too stressful. You literally go in not knowing if you'll have by a job by the end of the day if you don't meet the target for sign ups
- The hours they give you will probably be longer than advertised because most days you have to travel by train somewhere else
- Have a weird policy about not signing up students under 25 that was infuriating, especially when one of the sites was literally right next to a uni of 30,000 students & they were way more likely to stop and want to donate than any other demographic I saw.

pros:
"I'm not a retail specialist,  so I'm not going to get my hands dirty in designing how we set out our shops."  
              Mark Goldring. CEO
               Huffington Post,  circa 2013
cons: To  all overworked,  undervalued & inadequately supported shop managers  the above quote from Mark Goldring explains it all. As an ex-manager I have only one response to make; "Shame on you!"

review_title: Started optimistic but disappointed within three months. Feel mislead about the role.
pros: Worthwhile cause, meet new people, interesting and varied work, no two days the same, helpful area management. Regular management meetings.
cons: Unrealistic expectations for part time managers- full time job part time pay. No real authority as Oxfam proposes that volunteers run the shop, yet tel managers to be entrepreneurs, and to treat the shop as your own: direct conflict with volunteers. No support for the managers when dealing with problem volunteers. Too much unnecessary admin. Appalling waste of money via shops. Appalling lack of training. Managerslayed off against each other. Too pushy re sales targets etc. - relentless and unreasonable expectations when you're dealing with donated stock!

review_title: Working with Oxfam makes you feel helpful
pros: I'ts great volunteering with Oxfam, you feel like you belong there, although a lot of work needs to be done, you feel like it's all worth while, you feel like you are helping vulnerable people where ever there is a crisis.
cons: There is'nt much negative aspects with volunteering with Oxfam, although reaching monthly targets was a challenge but it's all to do with putting your soul and energy into the charity because you know that the more we push ourselves the better the outcome is, more people get the help they need elsewhere

job_title: Warehouse Matierials Controller in Bicester, England
pros: I have worked for oxfam supply centre for 25yrs now. I love my job and the people i work with.I have seen people come and go in my time here.I would not change my job for nothing.I work to help all the the struggling people in the world. If we have a disater to respond to then its a case of all hands on the work floor to prepare the stock for the disaster.I dont mind if that means coming in early or going home late.I have a home to go to the disater i am responding to the people may not have anything.And thats why i love my job as i am helping people in need.
cons: I cant really think of any down sides to working for oxfam.As i love my job thats why i have stuck at it for 25yrs.

pros: Lovely people, people smile at you when you go around the building, happy purposeful atmosphere, pretty social, really people-oriented which was a refreshing change from 6 years of corporate automata. Work is challenging (every organisation has its challenges) but you can ask for help and not get looked down upon. Really flexible approach to working - alternative patterns, home working some days a week, worth asking when you apply what they might consider. So great to working for an organisation with a genuine mission to do some good in the world and stand up for what it believes in.
cons: Salary below market rate but the flexible working makes up for it in spades.

pros: My shop manager was great, very helpful and proactive at getting things down career-wise. It is nice to get involved in the wider community, both locally and of course internationally. Communication between the lower levels of management is good.
cons: Decision making could be sped up somewhat, it seems to become slower and slower to get an answer as you seek further up the ladder. With it being a charity the pay is not the best, but thats to be expected. Next to no contact with managers beyond the "area" level unfortunately.

job_title: Human Resources Administrator in Oxford, England
pros: Pros – Great chance to work in a highly professional, international yet ethical job. If you are lucky there are  travel opportunities. Lots of opportunities to work with people around the world. Friendly working culture. Good offices. Good for the CV.
cons: Cons – Can seem removed from the field work on the ground. HR is focused only on developing top management and people on lower level jobs tend to be very talented/experienced but move on due to lack of encouragement/development. Pay is low (but you wouldn't work there for the money).

pros: Amazing co-workers. Good work-life balance. I found it relatively easy to get a promotion within the organisation and change my location during five years that I spent within it.
cons: The organisation was undergoing restructuring at various levels all five years that I was part of it. Constant change of strategies was very time consuming and de-motivating for staff. A lot of good people left in the meantime, as they no longer understood where they belonged.

job_title: Cashier in Henley on Thames, England
pros: It helps overcome famine, natural disasters, illnesses, etc. Oxfam and all its workers work hard to help all these people suffering in many different countries around the world, not only in Africa as many believe but also in Latin America, Russia, etc.
cons: Working alongside many people from different sectors can be challenging but I have learnt from this brilliant experience so much knowledge and experiences that I can use in other aspects of life. I am very proud of being able to say I am part of it!

review_title: Interesting people to work with in an organisation to be proud of
pros:
Most employees (most of my experience is at Head Office) are good people who have interesting life stories. So generally colleagues are a pro. Worklife balance excellent: working part time is not frowned upon.
Plenty of opportunities to work in other parts of the organisation as it is so large and varied.
cons: You won't make your fortune working here. You have to count every penny (as you should do in a charity) so it's not for someone who likes an expense account or company car.

review_title: Very Dedicated Staff with some Dysfunctional Management
job_title: Business Development Representative in Oxford, England
pros:
- The dedication of the people who work at Oxfam can never be questioned and it is very inspiring to work with such motivated colleagues who are striving to make the world a better and more equal place.
- Opportunity work internationally thanks to the confederation structure
- You can see the real impact of your work on peoples lives
- As a confederation Oxfam is re-balancing the distribution of power to the Global South
cons:
- Can sometimes be too academic in it's approach to practical problems
- Internal politics can be very disruptive
- Constantly changing goal posts (in my personal experience)
- International Programmes Team Staff always look stressed and over-worked with challenging work/life balance

pros: Oxfam's very much on a par with the other major aid agencies as a place to work. There are a wealth of international postings for those with the opportunities to take them. The atmosphere is consistently warm and friendly.
cons: The opportunities for career progression are limited for those without a huge amount of pre-existing experience.  There is too much bureaucracy, excessive meetings and not as much dynamism as one sees in the private sector.

pros: Healthy, friendly environment. Flexible working hours. Good management. It has been a pleasure working for Oxfam and having the chance to visit many locations both in the UK and abroad so as to fully understand the extent of its action and the benefits it brings to the needy.
cons: Quite a low pay considering equivalent jobs in other companies. Benefits almost non existent. Oxford is a very expensive area to live in and no compensation is offered whatsoever. Alternatively if you chose to live further away, again no travel compensation is offered.

job_title: Voluntary Shop Assistant in Liverpool, England
pros: The team was very friendly and helpful. Also got to meet alot of different customers from all walks of life who made the job very rewarding and made no two day the same! I was also given the opportunity to learn a broad range of new skills such as till work, basic accounting and pricing and labelling stock.
cons: As the team were so nice it would have been nice to have had the opportunity to engage in some after team activities such as being part of a sports team or doing something in particular for charity eg sponsored run.

pros:
The money is raised for places like India, China & Hong Kong . To give clean water , clothing ,  nice shoes and not to live in poor unhealthy conditions (Not the refurbish the office) . Mangers are very helpful and polite ,
 quite hours, not so busy & relaxing environment Free light refreshments eg. Tea , coffee & biscuits
cons:
10 min lunch break , no Coner cuttings . 
On the till most of the time (no training either)
Cleaning & dusting the shop floor , display windows  , toilets & staff kitchen

pros: One of the best organisations at fighting poverty in the world. Friendly, intelligent, passionate colleagues. Supportive, reflective culture and good opportunities for learning and development.
cons: The HQ location on the outskirts of Oxford limits the pool of people to recruit from and the organisation does not take advantage of modern working practices to overcome this. Senior management place a lot of value on staff being in the office, when in reality the majority of staff could work elsewhere.

pros: Our mission is amazing - and seeing how your work helps disadvantaged people around the world is incredible.  Decent life-work balance. Generally the work is interesting and allows for you to learn on the job.
cons: Pay is poor compared to global sector.  Money goes to the beneficiaries not our management systems - so these suffer and you often find yourself having to make do in the job.

review_title: Welcoming and pleasant working environment, but limited opportunities
job_title: Customer Service Assistant Volunteer in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros:
Good, in-depth training on all aspects of working in the store, generally pleasant and flexible working environment with friendly team members. 

Volunteer scheme can fill in gaps in CV, increase skill-set and help people move into work elsewhere. 

Contributing in a small way towards a good cause.
cons:
No prospect of paid roles for volunteers and no opportunities for progression. Oxfam has the luxury of being able to recruit volunteers from an inexhaustible pool of young unemployed people, graduates and others who are down on their luck and who will often put in long hours over extensive periods of time (and so will have all the skills and experience required for the job). Oxfam appears disinterested in creating paid roles as a result. Volunteers are disposable, with few staying in the long-run as the roles are only really helpful as a stop-gap. Meanwhile, managers are paid disproportionately large sums. This does not seem fair. 

Can also feel demoralising if you are volunteering and are not fully appreciated, or chastised unfairly. After volunteering for around a month and moving on to a new job (which I informed the manager about, explicitly explaining I would be unable to return for the forseeable future as my hours were uncertain, but I might be able to work something out at a later date), I received an angry and patronising phone call a week later, pushily demanding to know why I hadn't informed them if I would be returning by then and reminding me that I had a "commitment to the team". 

This bizarre incident, as well as some of the impatient/rude customer reactions I received when I was giving up my own time for no reward, made me wary of going into similar voluntary positions in the future.

Staff are not really made aware of global issues Oxfam is supposed to be tackling, and how much of the funds raised go towards the cause itself is dubious. Certain business practices could be made more ethical e.g. lack of recycling facilities, products can be priced unfairly (using online prices and adding their P&P fees to calculate the Oxfam item price), aforementioned lack of benefits for volunteers.

pros:
- Great training opportunities
- Great opportunity to run large projects
- Amazing people
- They believe in you
- The Oxfam 'magic' - the culture feels worldly, kind and worthwhile
- Reduced levels of process allows you to get on with things quickly
cons:
- Some politics at senior levels
- Salaries are lower (as you'd expect)
- Some pockets of people with a negative outlook who don't get the 'real mission'!

pros:
Good for expansion of skills 
Leading charity - sets high standards 
Good people and nice feel about the place 
Respected Brand and quality approach to projects & changes
cons:
Too complicated has been recognised - but not addressed successfully 
Poor man management is not addressed 
Inefficiency in people churn is frustrating , and limiting 
Career progression is poor

review_title: Very friendly and try to help you get connected within the organisation
pros: Everyone I met was very welcoming and supportive, even though I was 'only an intern'. Several senior members of staff gave me their time to chat over coffee or lunch about the work they were doing. There are regular seminars about development and poverty where people can bounce ideas around. There is a lot of very creative thinking coming from brilliant minds at Oxfam GB.
cons: Interns are not paid. This meant I could only afford to intern for four months before I ahd used all my savings and needed a paying job.

job_title: Volunteer in Bury St Edmunds, England
pros: I was a volunteer in the bookshop. I gained a lot of retail experience and got my confidence back. There was a laid back atmosphere. The other volunteers were very nice and so was the manager. There was only one person I didn't get on with. We had good chats about the world while sorting the books. Free coffee and biscuits.
cons: No pay. Some volunteers are lazy and happy to let you do all the work. Messy and squashed back room.

review_title: Shop manager's treated with contempt by employer
pros: none - get opportunity to go to the festivals? get to look at other people's rubbish?
cons:
if you are a shop manager then you will be expected to work over and above your paid hours - you also have problems trying to get your holiday entitlement as you have to rely on volunteers to be in charge while youre away and do everything you normally do
terrible pay for the enormous workloads and exhaustion is commonplace - oh yes the younger staff working at head office are in a bubble of middle class 'niceness' and need to get out to see how the shops really make the money that pay their wages

pros: Great fun to work with colleagues in a fast paced workplace. Will recommend as all the work put in  is for the the eradication of poverty mission.
cons: Pricing and listing donations can become tedious and boring especially on the weekend. There was virtually no management in the store I worked at if you needed to speak to them.

review_title: Too many elephants in the room...
pros: Influential well-known organisation. More open that most to new ideas. Great office space to work in. Friendly colleagues. Flexible working. Potential for progression if your face fits
cons: Managers not held to account and quality of management determines your experience. Some controlling behaviours remain unchecked and poor performance not consistently dealt with. Lots of talk of learning which does not happen. What you say and how is valued more than delivery. Some technically weak staff promoted well-beyond competence/ experience.

pros:
More or less complete autonomy in running your own store with minimal interference from line managers.
Recruiting and working with a great team of volunteers towards our mission to reduce inequality. 
Working with our customers to achieve  above.
cons:
Being self motivated sometimes for months with little contact from other managers as well as silo working with same.
Little support apart from that provided by the local shop team, even when the shop is experiencing difficulties.

pros: Great ethics and morals, great place to work
cons: too many meetings and while I was there there was a lack of identity, but the CEO was planning on making changes, both in terms of size and structure, and in terms of direction and focus.

pros: Great chance to experience working at the hub of an international NGO. Lots of travel opportunities. Lots of opportunities to work with people around the world. Friendly working culture (at least it was when I was there), with social events. Laid back dress code.
cons: Very process orientated. Difficult to 'get things done' due to onerous sign-off procedures. Very administrative and far removed from the field work on the ground. Lack of middle ranking jobs, so can be difficult to progress and be promoted.

pros: Light, spacious building, canteen on site, great career progression, good emphasis on personal goal setting, friendly teams, sense of purpose. Company values and mission are at the heart of all they do.
cons:
Long, often tedious processes to get things done.
Lower salary scales then other organisations

pros: Now I'm doing a volunteer in Manchester while I'm looking for a job. I will do Volunteering in a bookshop charity, in oxfam. I think it will help me to grow personally and improve my english level, and I have always liked to help people. I think it will help me to meet new people and to have a better adaptation to the English culture.
cons: I don't think that a Volunteer have cons. It will be help me to adapt Manchester and meet new people.

job_title: Senior Technical Advisor in Oxford, England
pros: Lovely warm-hearted people with great values, focus on social change, relatively good in raising most important societal issues, for an NGO high level of influence
cons: Low quality mid-level and even top-level management, too big and hierarchical, low level of accountability, lack of an open discussion culture, in 2014 and 2015 organisation underwent a major reshuffle and restructuring associated with many problems

pros: friendship between the team in the shop, a day goes very quickly,each day many treasures come in and it is exciting getting the goods sorted and priced, out on the shop floor and sold. after all one persons rubbish is another persons treasure.
cons: rude customers, no benefits,no staff discount,very rare protional prospects.

review_title: I have  an amazing experience working with people from all over the world
pros: Oxfam is one of the best employer for diverse workforce, you get good opportunity to learn about different people from different back ground.
cons: There is no follow up on the diverse workforce in order to make sure that each individuals are integrated with in the culture of Oxfam. just only recruiting diverse workforce does not mean diversity and inclusiveness is fulfilled.

review_title: Good ethics, little to no acknowledgement for big efforts
job_title: Lead Production Coordinator in London, England
pros:
Lots of fun organisiing large scale events for the chartiy
Great People
Flexible working hours
cons:
Little to no money 
Expect to be working late into the night (3 - 4 in the morning)

pros: Great staff flexibility and ok salaries for sector with wonderful clever colleagues.
cons: V weak leadership team and no clear direction across organisation. Management by consensus which is always a fail plus very weak staff development pathways, despite huge amount of money and resource spent on L&D. There are literally no staff development pathways. They spend masses on training staff but never have clear pathways.

review_title: I have enjoyed the experience very much. Definitely gonna work there again if I have the time. Boost up your CV too.
pros: The staff was very friendly and working there was very relaxed. The work experience was very enjoyable. It has also improved my communication skills as well.
cons: Sometimes you have to work after hour. There could be some miss communication with some employees because they can't speak a lot of English

pros: 33 days annual leave. Some flexible working.
cons: Bullying line managers who like to shout at you. No anti bullying policy. They won't listen unless you take out a formal grievance. Even then they'll close ranks.  No support from the union or HR. Senior management denies bullying is an issue, and actually close rank to block complaints. Intense performances reviews, you end up being told you're not good enough every 12 months. Line managers don't approve legitimate expenses, leaving you out of pocket.

review_title: As the umbrella of a very loose confederation, focussed on governance, it is a group striving for quality and excellence
pros: Inspiring mission, central place in a global organisation, organisation with a great reputation and influence
cons: influence within Oxfam is restrained due to lack of resources and the voluntary nature of the support of the currently  17 Oxfam organisations

review_title: Very friendly colleagues and meet a variety of people every day. The manager is very considerate and we are well trained
pros: Friendly manager, friendly staff, variety everyday, provides training, excellent work experience.
cons: The only downside is that there is no pay- but it is really enjoyable work!

review_title: Not good time to work at Oxfam: weak leaders/HR, sexist and arrogant colleagues are common
pros:
Some of the nicest people you'll work with anywhere below middle management!

Some pockets of interesting work, but increasingly hard to find.
cons:
BIg restructure underway. Very uncomfortable stage of process. 

HR Is weak and don't feel like partners. new contracts are issued really slowly after weeks and lots of people are working for long periods without technically being covered by contracts; sense is often that you're bothering staff if you go to them for help and hard to find someone who knows how to advise you on benefits and policies; department not somewhere you would trust with personal issues.

Don't know any staff who got an induction except for in the shops. Really tough to know how to do things if you have an unattentive manager. Lots of the positive reviews on this website seem to be from people in shops which possibly suggests that they actually manage them, which is unlike most staff in head office. Internal training is also hard to come by, especially on policies and managment.

Very common for female colleagues who have kids and challenging hours/roles to be told that they can't have flexible working, they should probably not go for promotions because they have children and can't travel etc by bosses before it even gets to HR. Maternity policy doesn't seem to exist for  women on fixed term contracts which are really common in the organization (and sector). 

Very common to hear about my female colleagues being told not to be too 'emotional' when they try to raise issues with how they are treated by organization or colleagues- also experienced myself. Heard very strange comments about gender work by senior leaders.

Head office is surprisingly undiverse and seems to attract tons of new staff who are under-experienced from other sectors and captures people wanting to stay in Oxford which isn't always best people for org. so is sense that many friends hire friends who don't want to commute to London (head hunting or paying consultants).

No people strategy in Oxfam for years so bosses rely on good will of staff who are smart and caring people working til burn out as workloads are way too high. Know dozens of colleagues who burnt out and left on really unhappy terms- managers really missing something here.

Bullying is another reason lots of colleagues have talked about for leaving and it's often not dealt with well. Colleagues in some teams have left a lot of feedback about problems with bosses but people complained about never seem to hear that feedback and then eventually they leave of their own accord after loads of their line reports have already left Oxfam.

When you talk to people you know well is really clear salaries aren't even across pay bands, and different divisions and people from outside always get more money for the same jobs because internals have no negotiating power. 

Leadership don't convey that they listen to staff or value them - real sense that a lot of senior leaders are in it for themselves, which you wouldn't expect at Oxfam. Also hard to know what they value themselves other than achieving the restructure. Hard to find seniors who are any good at comms.

review_title: Sorely Disappointed at how Oxfam has gone downhill over the years
pros: In the days I worked for Oxfam there was a great structure in place - I got to work with super line managers, fellow Oxfam colleagues and an energetic, motivated bunch of volunteers, and it was also a great social hub with friends I kept for years after I left. It was my most loved job ever, I loved the diversity of tasks as a retail manager and loved that our joint efforts had a meaningful end result helping those in poverty. In the days I worked for Oxfam we were treated very 'inclusively', trained amazingly and got to learn about projects first hand.
cons: It was hard work and underpaid at the time I worked for Oxfam  (late 90s to 2000). But recently (2019) I joined a new Oxfam retail venture as a volunteer, which I enjoyed at some level. But as time ticked by I got to witness situations that would never have been allowed back in the day. I was never inducted (fundamental to retaining volunteers), I was never included nor involved in what projects were current, I was offered free fair-trade chocolate and discount on clothing (this was not allowed before), I was given a free reign to come and go as I pleased, which I appreciated at some level, but it all comes down to serious lack of structure. The final straw was when I witnessed the paid deputy manager shouting at a volunteer for doing something wrong, telling him off in front of me (don't think she knew I was there) - with english not being his first language, he had not understood the task in the first place. I was horrified not to mention very upset by this. It seems there has been 'new blood' injected into Oxfam and its tainted. After this incident and observing a few instances of lack of integrity I left, sorely disappointed and disillusioned.

pros: Oxfam opens opportunity for students to contribute their time and their share for the community. It is a professional charity shop in which working there can help students to find their time valuable. They can learn from the work, manager, colleagues and develop communication skills. Working environment is open and it is easy to broader network.
cons: I just worked for a month; hence, nothing was difficult for me.

job_title: Team Membr in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros:
giving back to the community
fulfilling role
good work experience especially for cv or university application 
knowing you're making a positive contribution to society ie rasing money for war striken areas or natural disaster victime
cons:
can get monotonous sometimes having to complete the same task but that is the same for every jobs
having to get used to customers trying to haggle prices in a charity shop
rude customers
the smell of clothes donated

pros: My shop manager was very down to earth and great to work with. I learned a lot how a NGO functions and gets things done.
cons: There was a sense of too much politics within the Shop as well as with regional mangers who would come to visit the shop.

job_title: Retail Store Manager in Swanage, England
pros:
Great support from head office and field management
Gret cause motivates you and you have freedom to merchandise and run your shop
cons:
Low salary but its the cause that motivates you and empowerment from th e mnagement
Sorry but its the only negative thing thaat

job_title: Volunteer in Beeston, East Midlands, England
pros:
-Easy job, doesn't require anything just being able to do some customer service when people can't find something 
-Awesome manager
-No interview
-If you work all day you can get a £3 free lunch
-You make friends with the volunteers
-You get some experience that can be later be useful for retail shops or anything like that
cons:
- Working all day can be exhausting
-You don't get paid (volunteer work)

pros: The fellow volunteers are welcoming and friendly. This makes the atmosphere an enjoyable one to work in.
cons: While I loved my time at Oxfam volunteering I needed to start earning a wage and therefore had to leave as other commitments got in the way.

pros: You get to meet a mixture of people, both when meeting customers and also fellow coworkers. It is also a great way to train skills for other jobs.
cons: The pay is low or none if there on a voluntary basis and the organisation can be chaotic. There isn't much of a over-arching standard on how it functions at the more detailed level.

pros:
Many pros and some cons. 

Life changing experience , if you are looking to make a difference in this world. I met some of the smartest people in my life , some I'm happy to call friends years after.

If you have the opportunity to work for Oxfam, please do.
cons: Any organisation with a substantial size has some drawback but overall nothing to complain about

pros: It's brilliant to work for a cause you are passionate about, and with people who are equally inspired. There are are many benefits (such as flexible working hours etc) but you are expected to do a lot of (unpaid) overtime.
cons: There are so many hardworking and dedicated people that the underperformers really stand out.

review_title: Used to be my best job ever
pros:
Contact with and travel to 100+ countries.
A real sense of doing something for a good cause. This is important to me.
cons:
Can get bureaucratic at times.
Constant changes and restructures.
Sometimes the initiatives to "save money" (huge pressure on charities) can backfire into spending more, actually.

job_title: Volunteer In Store in Grimsby, England
pros:
Helped me develop skills to go into the working world, lovely team and learnt alot. Also helped me dealing with social anxiety, management were very understanding and arguably one of the reasons I can work today.
If I could have secured paid employment here I would have.
cons:
Could get quite hectic when deliveries came in.
Untidy. 
Unpaid (understandably as a volunteer).

pros: It is my fourth month in the UK and nearly 3.5 months, I have been working for Oxfam Newcastle Shop as a volunteer. The staff is great and I wish I could work for them as a paid staff. As a teacher, I generally teach but not I'm learning. I love you all guys!
cons: Nothing! Everything is really great

pros: The people were lovely, made me feel welcome! Always had a good time, and was satisfied with helping other people in poorer countries.
cons: Not many cons, the only thing i didn't like was that they didn't have enough money to fix up parts of the shop, but that's just one shop, i'm sure there aren't many that need fixing.

pros:
Choose own role
Chance to try other shop role
cons:
No connection between managers and staff
Staff shortages
Poor atmosphere
When I joined extra off site training and staff socializing was major points,  never happened 
Poor volunteer support
New manager does little except talk about herself

pros:
Very low pressure work
Rewarding and fulfilling
Hours are totally up to you
Valuable experience can be gained on the till/helping customers
cons:
On quieter days the shift can get boring
Training is very brief but everything can be learnt yourself very easily in a small amount of time

job_title: Retail Store Manager in Chichester, England
pros: given a free hand running the store, left to create the look you want in the shop
cons: pay is not great, lots of pressure for the money paid. lots of rent paid and not much to show for it.

pros: Get to work with dedicated volunteers and raise money to overcome poverty and suffering.
cons: There is never enough hours in the day to get everything done.

pros: Getting to work with a range of books. meeting nice, friendly customers and staff. Feeling like you are contributing to a worthy cause.
cons: Wages in charity sector notoriously low. Not much responsibility. Little information about progression. Some staff not open to new ways of doing things/ new ideas.

review_title: A very friendly and relaxed environment
pros: A charity that values its employees and offer good work life balance. Some really lovely and friendly people to work with.
cons: Very low payscales. Some of the senior management is not in touch with how much things have 'moved on' from the days in which Oxfam was leading the way.

pros:
- The job is full-on, and therefore exciting
- Lots of variety in tasks
- Responsibility is given quickly
cons:
- Too hierarchical
- Cynical atmosphere where the funding was more important than the cause

pros: I worked part timeduring sixth form. Was great for my personal statement for university. I didnt do duke of ediburgh so it looked better I like to think.
cons: Not much money obviously. And the people vary. If you work in the shop then you can get all sorts.

pros: Good people, organised and very friendly. Provide assistance when needed and the customers are also very friendly.
cons: Long hours, can sometimes get a bit boring and quite hands on as new donated items can come throughout the day

pros: Excellent service from staff good service a d doing a great service accross the globe for those in need and driven from their homes
cons: Doing a great job but don't always get the backing they need from the public people should back this great team of people more

review_title: It was a great place to work
pros: Helping customer and helping the charity was amazing and had a really good atmosphere and friendly place to work and made friends
cons: People stealing and stealing the clothes from outside the shop that people donated (not staff) and some people didnt wanna be friends

review_title: Good if you are entrusted with autonomy
pros: Able to obtain differerent transferable skills useful for other positions in the future. Enthusiastic shop managers and volunteers. Should ask for a more demanding role in the shop to learn more things
cons: Not really helpful if you are stucked with those monotoneous and boring tasks.

job_title: Finance Assistant in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: Lack of a strong company culture
cons:
Good experience of working in an office 
Lunch money and travel money if needed 
Presentation about how our work even one day a week volunteering made all the difference

review_title: Like a family - and caring for the world
job_title: Volunteer in Bradford, Yorkshire and the Humber, England
pros:
--help make a difference to the world 
--supportive staff and management
--work life balance is great
cons: --absolutely none! keep up the good work.

review_title: Difficult work and purely target driven
pros: People are friendly and seem to want you to do well.
cons: Not hitting your targets means you’re gone. This is okay as a summer job but so stressful if you’re looking for long term management.

pros:
Rewarding experience - you're taught new skills 
There's always something to do
Friendly staff
The feeling of helping others all around the world!
cons: There aren't really any negatives as such as its a volunteer position, however it can be slightly boring when the shop is empty

review_title: Hard Work, Little Support, Felt Undervalued
pros:
Rewarding Experience
Good to help people
cons:
Felt there was little support from the regional and head office level
Low pay, and not enough hours to meet expected workload. Paid shop staff often seem to work more hours than they are contracted for out of obligation.

pros: Friendly Staff, agreeable work hour. I was offered a discount on a bass guitar after working there for several months.
cons: It's a voluntary job so you won't get paid. You will however get experience with customer relations, shop handling etc.

review_title: a good career beginning  in the UK
pros:
friendly working environment and nice people around.
can try different work sections and find out what I really like.
cons:
too easy to spend money, even though cheap items but easily little bit everyday. 
some donations are quite rough conditions.

pros: Diverse range of people, mostly very committed to the cause, you get a lot of satisfaction from working for a global charity.
cons: Not much investment in staff development (though perhaps not too surprising considering the public's scrutiny at how their donations are being used).

pros: Everyone is very friendly there
cons: As a volunteer, you end up sorting out donation most of the time. Is like you have to find things to do for yourself, so when you first go there it can feel a bit lost.

pros: like being self employed as you earn your own salary and theirs
cons:
having to work with unreliable and self serving volunteers - line managers are just parroting the company line - its social conditioning and anyone who questions it is not a team player 
senior management are not fit to run a pub let alone a huge charity

pros: It does exciting and interesting work.
cons: Demotivated atmosphere due to restructure and changing external environment. People blame HR for everything they can't do. Doesn't encourage initiative. Some teams are cohesive but mine is not operated as a team.

pros: Great to talk to customers and the feeling that you have actually helped people
cons: None that I can really think of but sometimes the multi- tasking can get a bit too much

pros: A good place to learn aspicts of retail, part of a team of talanted people
cons: Not supportive if unwell or sick

review_title: Oxfam is a great place to be a volunteer
pros: meeting a lot of interesting people and managers are so friendly. all travel expenses are covered.
cons: i do not think there is any cons of working with oxfam,

job_title: Customer Service in Bishops Stortford, England
pros: Very good staff, I can have frequent breaks.
cons: I do not think there is any Con I found in the company.

review_title: Too much to do, too little pay and time to do it properly.
pros: Great Volunteers, Passionate team members.
cons: Poor pay for the job you're expected to do. Way too much paperwork. Managers constantly stressed and overworked across the shop network.

pros: Extremely rewarding job, opportunities to meet lots of incredible people both when working as well as the people you work alongside.
cons: Not for those who are unprepared to work hard or lack confidence

pros: making a small difference in the world one day at a time
cons: everything is keyed up to help the volunteers NOT the paid staff

pros:
Its a simply stressfree job, where you can gain lots of expereince, from working at the counting to pricing products.

Travel cost reimbursed.
Free snakes.
cons: The only down in working at oxfam there is only volunteer part-time.

pros: Flexible hours, sick pay and in house cafeteria. Try to look after staff health however, management aren't great at it.
cons: Different rules for various workers. Selfish back stabbing attitude.  Salaries are awful unless you are senior management status and on more than double normal workers.

pros: Great staff, great office and great job
cons: Bad location (I commute from London and even from Oxford its complex)

pros: Great work experience, love the customers and staff
cons: Harassment and bullying from Management in Purley Oxfam.

job_title: Customer Relationship Management Support in Oxford, England
pros: The People, Company Culture, Noble work
cons: I think Senior Management could have helped people progress into different areas of work, it's a shame Oxfam and other charities don't always offer graduate schemes

review_title: Good employer with a commitment to developing people
pros:
Invests in staff
Good retention record
Relatively strong on diversity
Invests in management development
Good terms and conditions
Attractive on CV
Lots of opportunities

review_title: Enjoyable time with the OXFAM family
job_title: Professional Street Fundraiser in Glasgow, Scotland

cons: Working in the street and dealing with any kind of people. A lot of rejections before you finally succeed.

pros: Volunteers and customers are fantastic
cons: Expectations on part-time managers completely unrealistic, if you consider a shop manager role then I'd only advise a minimum 30hr week contract .

pros: Good to help, boosts your CV, meet new people of different nationalities.You learn handling cash, be responsabile and working with a team.

pros: Spent a year volunteering at an Oxfam bookshop in Alderley Edge. Great fun, lovely colleagues and bosses.
